title: Why do armies follow dictators? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends, but for the most part, it’s because of power politics and privilege. Essentially, dictators have no actual political legitimacy — not since the Roman Republic fell, at least (because Roman dictators were traditionally elected, as opposed to modern dictators) — which means that there is no institutional framework justifying their stay in power. As a result, they are forced to look for, let’s call them, “alternative” means of staying in power. These alternative means are the armed forces, typically. It’s not hard to see why, either: the military is essentially the one institution in a state with the most hard power available. A dictator that relied on the judiciary or legislative arms would get overthrown easily simply because they would lack actual coercive mechanisms to force the population and government to do what they want. This gives the military leverage — if the dictator takes care of them, then they take care of the dictator. Quid pro quo. Thus, in dictatorships, some of the best-maintained officials in the administration tend to be military figures. Generals, colonels — essentially the higher-ups in the military food chain, though the lower ranks are also provided for far better than the average citizen. As a result, the dictator now has the means to essentially force through whatever changes they want with impunity because — let’s be honest here — who’s going to punish them when they have the backing of the military? The police? The judiciary? “What’s right”? “Popular opinion”? So that’s why the armies tend to follow dictators — because the dictators make sure to keep them happy. The moment they fail to do so is typically the moment the army turns on them. Exceptions do occur, however.

response.answer_text: There is no single answer, but, judging from what I know about our military coups in Latin America, I believe there are four main reasons: Military dictators are perceived by the military as “one of them” and catering for their needs, even a long-time dictator, like Stroessner. In this sense, the Armed Forces effectively loot the country for their own good, amassing wealth, acquiring property and getting privilege and immunity.Dictators imposed by a stronger foreign power (usually the USA) are accepted, even begrudgingly, because the military knows that the alternative is a war they’d lose.In Latin America, as a rule of thumb, armed forces are more for social control than for national defense: their usual enemy is the people, not foreign invaders. Some Latin American countries haven’t fought many wars, but have been very active politically. Argentina had not fought any wars since the third quarter of the 19th century when it invaded the Falklands. Uruguayan military had not fought any wars since they consolidated their independence. Examples like this are common.Sense of hierarchy. In Latin America coups are always staged by the top tiers of the military, either on their own or backing a civil politician. We haven’t seen cases of coups breaching hierarchy, like other countries, in which coups were performed by captains (Burkina Faso), lieutenants (Ghana), colonels (Greece) or sergeants (Haiti and Cuba — these are the two exceptions that confirm the general rule).
